title: Valley of Dry Bones
shortSummary: Ezekiel 37 presents a powerful vision of restoration and hope for Israel through the imagery of dry bones coming to life. The chapter emphasizes God's promise to revive His people spiritually and physically, uniting the divided nation under one king and establishing an everlasting covenant of peace.
timeline: c. 593-571 BC - During the Babylonian exile, when Ezekiel prophesied to the captive Israelites

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and communicates God's vision and message of restoration to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Son of man
keyCharacters.description: A title used by God to address Ezekiel, emphasizing his humanity and prophetic role.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: Referred to as God's servant and future king over a united Israel, symbolizing the Messianic hope.

definitions.definition: To speak forth God's message as directed by the Holy Spirit, often involving future events or divine instruction.
Tendons or connective tissues that bind bones to muscles, symbolizing restoration of life and strength.
The breath or life-giving force from God, often representing the Holy Spirit or divine power.
An everlasting agreement initiated by God to bless and preserve His people in peace and fellowship.

outline.heading: The Vision of the Dry Bones
outline.description: God shows Ezekiel a valley full of dry bones and commands him to prophesy to them, resulting in their miraculous revival. This vision symbolizes God's power to restore life and hope to the spiritually dead nation of Israel.

outline.heading: Interpretation of the Vision
outline.description: God explains that the dry bones represent the whole house of Israel, who feel hopeless and cut off. He promises to open their graves, bring them back to their land, and put His Spirit within them so they will live.

outline.heading: The Sign of the Two Sticks
outline.description: Ezekiel is instructed to join two sticks representing Judah and Joseph (Ephraim), symbolizing the future reunification of the divided nation of Israel into one kingdom under Godâ€™s hand.

outline.heading: The Promise of a United Kingdom and Covenant
outline.description: God promises to cleanse Israel from sin, establish David as king, and make an everlasting covenant of peace. His sanctuary will dwell among them forever, demonstrating His presence and sanctification of Israel.

application: Trust in God's power to bring spiritual life and restoration even when situations seem hopeless or 'dead.'
Seek the infilling of the Holy Spirit, who gives true life and enables obedience to God's statutes.
Embrace God's promise of unity and peace within the body of Christ, reflecting His desire to reconcile and restore.
Live in the assurance of God's everlasting covenant, walking faithfully under His guidance and protection.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD unto these bones; Behold, I will cause breath to enter into you, and ye shall live:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's sovereign power to give life to what is dead, symbolizing spiritual resurrection and hope.

keyVerses.text: And shall put my spirit in you, and ye shall live, and I shall place you in your own land: then shall ye know that I the LORD have spoken it, and performed it, saith the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the transformative work of God's Spirit in restoring His people and fulfilling His promises.

keyVerses.text: And I will make them one nation in the land upon the mountains of Israel; and one king shall be king to them all: and they shall be no more two nations, neither shall they be divided into two kingdoms any more at all:
keyVerses.significance: This verse prophesies the future unity of Israel under one king, a foreshadowing of the Messianic kingdom.

keyVerses.text: Moreover I will make a covenant of peace with them; it shall be an everlasting covenant with them: and I will place them, and multiply them, and will set my sanctuary in the midst of them for evermore.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God's commitment to an eternal relationship of peace and presence with His people.
